title: Husband spent year and £100,000 renovating 'safe house' for wife allergic to him but it didn't go to plan
text:
Husband spent year and £100,000 renovating 'safe house' for wife allergic to him but it didn't go to plan Johanna Watkins suffers from a rare immune system disorder called Mass Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS) Share Joanna Watkins, with her husband Scott (Photo: Facebook) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A husband spent a year and £100,000 renovating a 'safe house' for his wife who is allergic to everything - including him. 
Johanna Watkins, 29, suffers from the rare immune system disorder Mass Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS). 
Her allergies are so severe that even being in the same space as her spouse, Scott, triggers a potentially life-threatening reaction . 
She cannot kiss or hold her other half's hand safely, and spends her evenings watching TV in a separate room to him. 
Johanna, from Minnesota US, has more than 100 allergies and has lost count of how many times she has been hospitalized after going into anaphylaxis - a potentially deadly condition. 
Dedicated husband Scott raised £100,000 through a GoFundMe page to transform their home into a space where Johanna could live comfortably. Johanna can't even be in the same room as her husband Scott due to her allergies (Photo: Gofundme) 
But he revealed that when Johanna entered her new home for the first time she passed out. 
"The smell of her space triggered her and she lost consciousness. 
"This was not the picture perfect moment (despite the TV cameras outside) we were waiting for. This was life or death," said Scott. Scott spent a year renovating a 'safe house' for Johanna (Photo: GoFundMe) 
Johanna regained consciousness shortly after and was bathed by her two brothers, the only people to whom she is not allergic. 
The couple are now hopeful she will get accustomed to her new environment. 
Scott, a school teacher, installed new paint, floors and furniture - all of it heated to kill any scents. 
Johanna's bedroom is pressurised, like a passenger jet. 
It uses a homemade, positive-pressure system that aims to keep her air scent-free and allergen-free. 
In their old home, Johanna lived in an attic room at her friend's home, which has sealed doors and windows and an air purification system. 
She only left this room to go to hospital or see a doctor. Johanna reacts severely to scents most people can't even detect (Photo: YouTube/Johanna Watkins) 
But Johanna's life wasn't always like this. Before she married Scott only three years ago, she was able to spend time hiking outside. 
Scott said he occasionally noticed that his wife would cough if they were face-to-face - but there were few signs of how bad she would get. 
Johanna's condition deteriorated rapidly. 
She could react to someone cutting an onion in the kitchen, despite her being three floors above. 
It was only last year when the couple realised they couldn't live together without endangering Johanna's life. 
Despite this, her committed husband returns home and cooks her dinner every night. Dedicated Scott cooks dinner for his wife every night (Photo: Facebook) 
She is only allowed to eat two dishes - beef stew and organic lamb. 
Anything else might set off her illness. 
"There is no easy way around this problem, I want to keep Johanna safe and me going to see her compromises her safety," Scott told the BBC . 
"We are absolutely committed to each other and we're going to wait as long as it takes to see if there is some type of healing," he added. 
MCAS is currently untreatable and comes with a number of unpleasant symptoms including coughing, cramping, nausea and the sense of feeling cold all the time. 
Sudden attacks can be triggered by stress, food, smells or even a slight change in temperature. Johanna had lived a normal life until only three years ago (Photo: Gofundme) 
Teenager reveals painful allergic reaction to routine hair dye patch test which 'saved her life' 
The condition has led Johanna to have reactions to everyday things, such as someone smoking "down the block" or pizza being cooked a mile away. 
On a dedicated GoFundMe page, Scott writes: "There is no known cure for this disease, and its treatment is a complicated puzzle." 
For now, Johanna is only able to see her siblings, who have become her carers and her only link with the outside world. 
However, even they have caused her to have minor reactions - despite wearing protective gear around her. 
The young woman knows her situation is dire, but she still has hope. 
"I have many gifts in my life that I have to be thankful for" she said. Like us on Facebook
